) Purpose: This IRM describes the process for certain returns not processed using a pipeline system for entry on the Master File (MF). These accounts must be recorded on a separate system called Non-Master File (NMF). Master File (NMF) accounts are a collection of revenue accounting transactions whose sole purpose is to provide a means for the assessment taxes and collection of revenue. • The Wage and Investment (W&I) and Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) Business Operating Divisions (BOD) are responsible for taxpayer relationships by: Providing general tax related information, Providing information on the status of taxpayer returns/refunds/ accounts, and Adjusting taxpayer accounts, when appropriate. • These responsibilities are divided into three subordinate units: Customer Assistance, Relationships, and Education (CARE) Customer Account Services (CAS) Compliance • To ensure taxpayer inquiries and accounts are addressed correctly, Taxpayer Assistance Centers (TAC), Accounts Management (AM), Compliance Services use the guidelines provided in IRM
, Account Services. (

) An overassessment (OA) is the portion of the assessment in excess of the correct tax liability. The method of adjusting OAs varies, depending on the amount has been paid, or whether the taxpayer has a balance owed on another module. Note: The amount to be abated is not limited to the outstanding balance on the module, but before issuing a refund or allowing a credit, check to ensure penalty and interest accruals are up to date and the Refund Statute tion Date (RSED) has not expired. (

) Adjust OAs by: a. Abating the OA b. Crediting the overpayment if the liability has been paid, but should be applied to another liability of the same taxpayer for some other tax or type of tax c. Refunding the OA if the liability has been paid and should not be as a credit to another liability (
) When an overassessment is determined, prioritize the application of the as follows:
Abatement of the outstanding amounts created from the assessment document.
Credit to any other outstanding liabilities for the same taxpayer for any taxable periods. The credit must be applied by the collection statute ration date (CSED). Internal Revenue Manual

) Current assessments are assessments of paid or unpaid tax liability, deﬁciency assessments or additional assessments resulting from regular amination. (

) Remittances received with the tax returns are assessed as current assess- ments, regardless of whether the return is: • Full paid • Overpaid • Part paid • Delinquent • Tentative • Subject to installment privileges (

) Deﬁciency Assessments are deﬁciencies in income, estate, gift taxes, and certain excise taxes (including assessable penalties and interest), the basis of determination made by: • Examination ﬁndings • Appeals ﬁndings • Tax Court decisions (IMF may be processed to MFT

) This category also includes: • Transferee assessments • Assessments based on remittances received with signed waivers cating agreement on Examination deﬁciencies • Assessments based on remittances tendered by taxpayers as on Examination deﬁciencies, as opposed to deposits made under
